newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Britain's Prince Charles visits Bangladesh town.
newsitem.headline: Britain's Prince Charles visits Bangladesh town.

text.p: Thousands of Bangladeshis welcomed Britain's Prince Charles on Thursday in the remote tea-growing district of Sylhet, one of the country's largest sources of emigrants to Britain.
"I feel very much at home here as a result of a large number of people from Sylhet who are now residents in Britain," the Prince of Wales told a reception given by Sylhet's town council.
About 95 percent of Bangladesh expatriates in Britain come from Sylhet. Officials estimate about 300,000 people from Sylhet have settled in Britain.
Earlier, colourfully dressed girls sang and danced as the heir to British throne flew into the city on the second day of a three-day trip to Bangladesh, a British colony until 1947.
Charles switched on a satellite telecommunications station built by British Telecom on the outskirts of Sylhet, about 340 km (210 miles) from the capital Dhaka.

"Ninety percent of the families in Sylhet have one or more relatives in England. This station would greatly help them keep a close contact," said Nargis Islam, a Sylhet resident whose daughter lives in London.
Thousands of people lined the 10-km (six mile) road from Sylhet airport to the town centre for a view of Charles.
"Joy (happily ever) Bangladesh, Joy Sylhet," Charles told the reception.
Before fyling to Sylhet, Charles visited a slum on the outskirts of Dhaka run by a British non-government organisation, ActionAid, and a child daycare centre.
